slides.title: Introduction to Geometry and Mensuration
slides.content:
Geometry deals with shapes, sizes, positions, and properties of figures, while Mensuration focuses on calculating measurements like length, area, perimeter, volume, and surface area of geometric figures. These topics are essential for SSC MTS exams and have practical applications in everyday life.

In this chapter, we will cover basic geometric concepts including lines, angles, triangles, quadrilaterals, and circles. We will also learn mensuration formulas for calculating perimeter, area, volume, and surface area of various 2D and 3D shapes.

Understanding these concepts will help you solve problems related to construction, land measurement, packaging, and many other real-world scenarios. Mastering the formulas and their applications is key to scoring well in this section.

slides.title: Lines and Angles
slides.content:
Line: A straight one-dimensional figure with no thickness, extending infinitely in both directions.

Line Segment: Part of a line with two endpoints.

Ray: Part of a line with one endpoint, extending infinitely in one direction.

Types of Angles:
1. Acute Angle: Less than 90° (e.g., 30°, 45°, 60°)
2. Right Angle: Exactly 90°
3. Obtuse Angle: Greater than 90° but less than 180° (e.g., 120°, 150°)
4. Straight Angle: Exactly 180°
5. Reflex Angle: Greater than 180° but less than 360°
6. Complete Angle: Exactly 360°

Angle Relationships:
- Complementary Angles: Two angles whose sum is 90°
- Supplementary Angles: Two angles whose sum is 180°
- Adjacent Angles: Share a common vertex and side
- Vertically Opposite Angles: Formed when two lines intersect (always equal)

Parallel Lines and Transversal:
- Corresponding Angles: Equal
- Alternate Interior Angles: Equal
- Alternate Exterior Angles: Equal
- Co-interior Angles: Sum = 180°

question.questionText: Two complementary angles are in the ratio 2:3. Find the larger angle.
question.explanation: Let angles be 2x and 3x. Sum = 90°, so 2x + 3x = 90, giving 5x = 90, x = 18. Larger angle = 3x = 54°.

slides.title: Triangles - Properties and Types
slides.content:
Triangle: A closed figure with three sides and three angles.

Angle Sum Property: Sum of all angles in a triangle = 180°

Types by Sides:
1. Equilateral: All sides equal, all angles = 60°
2. Isosceles: Two sides equal, two base angles equal
3. Scalene: All sides different, all angles different

Types by Angles:
1. Acute Triangle: All angles < 90°
2. Right Triangle: One angle = 90°
3. Obtuse Triangle: One angle > 90°

Pythagorean Theorem (for right triangle):
Hypotenuse² = Base² + Height²
h² = b² + h²

Important Pythagorean Triplets:
3-4-5, 5-12-13, 8-15-17, 7-24-25

Area of Triangle:
1. Area = (1/2) × Base × Height
2. Area = √[s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)] (Heron's Formula)
   where s = (a+b+c)/2 (semi-perimeter)

Perimeter = Sum of all three sides

slides.title: Quadrilaterals
slides.content:
Quadrilateral: A closed figure with four sides and four angles. Sum of all angles = 360°

1. Rectangle:
- Opposite sides equal and parallel
- All angles = 90°
- Diagonals equal and bisect each other
- Area = Length × Breadth
- Perimeter = 2(Length + Breadth)

2. Square:
- All sides equal
- All angles = 90°
- Diagonals equal, bisect at 90°
- Area = Side²
- Perimeter = 4 × Side
- Diagonal = Side × √2

3. Parallelogram:
- Opposite sides equal and parallel
- Opposite angles equal
- Diagonals bisect each other
- Area = Base × Height
- Perimeter = 2(a + b)

4. Rhombus:
- All sides equal
- Opposite angles equal
- Diagonals bisect at 90°
- Area = (1/2) × d₁ × d₂ (d = diagonals)

5. Trapezium:
- One pair of opposite sides parallel
- Area = (1/2) × (Sum of parallel sides) × Height

question.questionText: The length of a rectangle is 12 cm and breadth is 8 cm. Find its area.
question.explanation: Area of rectangle = Length × Breadth = 12 × 8 = 96 cm².

slides.title: Circles
slides.content:
Circle: A closed curve where all points are equidistant from a fixed point (center).

Key Terms:
- Radius (r): Distance from center to any point on circle
- Diameter (d): Longest chord passing through center, d = 2r
- Circumference: Perimeter of circle
- Chord: Line segment joining two points on circle
- Arc: Part of circumference
- Sector: Region between two radii and an arc
- Segment: Region between a chord and an arc

Formulas:
Circumference = 2πr = πd
Area = πr²

Sector:
Area of Sector = (θ/360°) × πr² (θ = angle in degrees)
Length of Arc = (θ/360°) × 2πr

Important Circle Properties:
- Angle in a semicircle = 90°
- Angles in same segment are equal
- Tangent is perpendicular to radius at point of contact

Remember: π ≈ 3.14 or 22/7

question.questionText: Find the circumference of a circle with radius 7 cm. (Use π = 22/7)

slides.title: 3D Shapes - Cube and Cuboid
slides.content:
Three-dimensional shapes have length, breadth, and height.

Cube:
All edges equal (side = a)
- Volume = a³
- Total Surface Area = 6a²
- Lateral Surface Area = 4a²
- Diagonal = a√3

Example: Cube with side 5 cm
Volume = 5³ = 125 cm³
TSA = 6 × 5² = 150 cm²

Cuboid:
Dimensions: Length (l), Breadth (b), Height (h)
- Volume = l × b × h
- Total Surface Area = 2(lb + bh + hl)
- Lateral Surface Area = 2h(l + b)
- Diagonal = √(l² + b² + h²)

Example: Cuboid 10cm × 8cm × 6cm
Volume = 10 × 8 × 6 = 480 cm³
TSA = 2(10×8 + 8×6 + 6×10) = 2(80 + 48 + 60) = 376 cm²

Note: Cube is a special case of cuboid where l = b = h

slides.title: Cylinder and Cone
slides.content:
Cylinder:
Radius = r, Height = h
- Volume = πr²h
- Curved Surface Area = 2πrh
- Total Surface Area = 2πr(r + h)

Example: Cylinder with r = 7 cm, h = 10 cm
Volume = (22/7) × 7² × 10 = 1540 cm³
CSA = 2 × (22/7) × 7 × 10 = 440 cm²

Cone:
Radius = r, Height = h, Slant Height = l
- l = √(r² + h²)
- Volume = (1/3)πr²h
- Curved Surface Area = πrl
- Total Surface Area = πr(r + l)

Example: Cone with r = 3 cm, h = 4 cm
Slant height l = √(9 + 16) = 5 cm
Volume = (1/3) × (22/7) × 9 × 4 = 37.71 cm³
CSA = (22/7) × 3 × 5 = 47.14 cm²

Note: Cone volume is 1/3 of cylinder volume with same base and height

question.questionText: Find the volume of a cube with side 6 cm.

slides.title: Sphere and Hemisphere
slides.content:
Sphere:
Radius = r
- Volume = (4/3)πr³
- Surface Area = 4πr²

Example: Sphere with radius 7 cm
Volume = (4/3) × (22/7) × 7³ = (4/3) × (22/7) × 343 = 1437.33 cm³
Surface Area = 4 × (22/7) × 7² = 616 cm²

Hemisphere (Half of sphere):
Radius = r
- Volume = (2/3)πr³
- Curved Surface Area = 2πr²
- Total Surface Area = 3πr² (includes flat circular base)

Example: Hemisphere with radius 7 cm
Volume = (2/3) × (22/7) × 343 = 718.67 cm³
CSA = 2 × (22/7) × 49 = 308 cm²
TSA = 3 × (22/7) × 49 = 462 cm²

Relationship:
Hemisphere volume = (1/2) × Sphere volume
Hemisphere CSA = (1/2) × Sphere surface area

slides.title: Prism and Pyramid
slides.content:
Prism:
A solid with uniform cross-section (base can be any polygon)
For rectangular/triangular base:
- Volume = Base Area × Height
- Lateral Surface Area = Perimeter of base × Height

Pyramid:
A solid with polygonal base and triangular sides meeting at apex
- Volume = (1/3) × Base Area × Height
- Lateral Surface Area = (1/2) × Perimeter × Slant Height

Square Pyramid:
Base side = a, Height = h, Slant height = l
- Volume = (1/3) × a² × h
- LSA = 2al
- TSA = a² + 2al

Note: Cone is a special pyramid with circular base

Example: Square pyramid, base side = 6 cm, height = 8 cm
Volume = (1/3) × 36 × 8 = 96 cm³

Key Difference:
Prism: Uniform cross-section, two identical bases
Pyramid: Comes to a point (apex), one base only

question.questionText: The radius of a sphere is 21 cm. Find its surface area. (Use π = 22/7)

slides.title: Important Conversions and Units
slides.content:
Length:
1 km = 1000 m
1 m = 100 cm
1 cm = 10 mm
1 m = 1000 mm

Area:
1 sq. km = 1,000,000 sq. m
1 sq. m = 10,000 sq. cm
1 hectare = 10,000 sq. m
1 acre = 4047 sq. m (approximately)

Volume:
1 cubic m = 1,000,000 cubic cm
1 liter = 1000 cubic cm
1 cubic m = 1000 liters

Weight:
1 kg = 1000 g
1 quintal = 100 kg
1 metric ton = 1000 kg = 10 quintals

Remember:
- Always convert to same units before calculation
- Check units in the answer options
- Area is always in square units
- Volume is always in cubic units

slides.title: Quick Formulas Summary
slides.content:
2D Shapes:
• Square: Area = a², Perimeter = 4a
• Rectangle: Area = l×b, Perimeter = 2(l+b)
• Triangle: Area = (1/2)×base×height
• Circle: Area = πr², Circumference = 2πr
• Rhombus: Area = (1/2)×d₁×d₂
• Trapezium: Area = (1/2)×(a+b)×h

3D Shapes:
• Cube: Volume = a³, TSA = 6a²
• Cuboid: Volume = l×b×h, TSA = 2(lb+bh+hl)
• Cylinder: Volume = πr²h, CSA = 2πrh
• Cone: Volume = (1/3)πr²h, CSA = πrl
• Sphere: Volume = (4/3)πr³, SA = 4πr²
• Hemisphere: Volume = (2/3)πr³, TSA = 3πr²

Tips for SSC MTS:
- Memorize all formulas
- Practice with π = 22/7 and π = 3.14
- Draw diagrams for complex problems
- Check if answer is in correct units
- Use Pythagorean triplets for quick calculation
